messageBody:
Sorry, I left out some information in my first posting: I am trying to
create a base class for similar tests that all need to go through the
same logic after a test failed/finished and I would like to put this
code in the common base class.
With JUnit 3 that was done by overriding runTest in TestCase and
catching/rethrowing the Throwable when calling super.runTest().


Thanks
Ralf


> You could set a flag at the end of your @Test:
>
> private boolean successful= false;
>
> @Test public void something() {
> ...
> successful= true;
> }
>
> @After public void postProcessing() {
> if (successful)
> throw new Party();
> }
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>

> Hello all,
>
> I am wondering, is it possible to retrieve information about the test
> context in which the @After method (or any other life cycle method) is
> called? In particular, in my @After method I would need to know
> whether the test has finished or failed.
>
> I played around with RunListener and my own runner implementation, but
> could not figure out how to retrieve a reference to the test class
> instance under execution in the RunListener or vice versa.
>
> Thanks and regards
> Ralf
